subject: fighting the anti-test-infection

messageBody:
I believe many in the xUnit community should now take advantage of
the opportunity to unwash brains WRT UI testing. What I mean:

The following came to me from a coder (in another company, though my
own probably has many similar instances of the following) who shall
remain nameless (unless he wants to paint a target on his back :-)

anonymous coder 02/08/2004 01:02 PM
> I'm on this project that is writing using a very-buggy,
> very-ready-any-day-now customized Swing-based UI. We have no tests,
> and no test framework or harness in place.

> Since I consider this a serious issue, (the project will easily
> exceed the 500,000 lines of code when it's done) I set about to make
> a useable test harness for unit testing the UI. What we'd like to do
> is (Test First) assert that each UI widget on each screen behaves
> according to our spec for all kinds of data going into the widget.
> Pretty standard TDD, wouldn't you think?

> Turns out the seriousness of this issue is not wholly shared by my
> peers, some of whom think testing is optional. Here's a quote from
> one of the core developers of the oh-so-not-ready-for-primetime
> customized Swing framework:

> You can build quality UI code without writing tests...

How did we get here? Here's my etiology, YMMV:

Once, not so long ago, some Big Brains cogitated, and sent forth the
idea (or perhaps this meme spoke through them):

"Code-time testing is Good. Cover completely, and enforce it with
build-time verification."

But from the trenches came the response, "The vast majority of us code
UIs--how can we test _those_ with xUnit tools?" Big heads scratched.
There were no UI automation tools short of monsters like WinRunner,
and manual testing is painful; both integrate with development
environments like fish ride bicycles. So the Big Brains said:

"Make your UIs thin, and test everything underneath them. That should
Be Good Enough."

And they were, and are, right: if you are very disciplined, and keep
logic and state in your UIs to absolute minima, and test everything
else, you can usually get by. But

- almost no one's that disciplined. Bosses want a fix NOW, or you
hafta work with UI code that's already thick, or there's some other
reason to just stick a _little_ bit of logic in there ... and you've
got a bigger hole in your coverage.

- the Doctrine of Incomplete Testing spreads by induction.
Coders, in our laziness, impatience, and hubris, tend to think:

· thin == !(required to test)

· my Foo is a thin extension of Bar!

· therefore I need not test it

Unfortunately, those thin layers tend to gather together into
big piles of buggy crap. This is the "anti-test-infection."

- over time, the big brains were UNDERSTOOD to have said,

"Make your UIs thin, and test everything underneath them. That is
Enough."

Meanwhile, thanks to tools built on, e.g., java.awt.Robot, now you
CAN "go the last mile": you can automate and test your UIs just as
you test the rest of your code, and at the same time, and using your
fave xUnit tooling. As the capability arose, so did the myth of its
expendability :-(

IMHO the word needs to go out: test your @#$^%&* UIs, too! A thin UI
is still good ... because it's easier to test. But a well-designed,
untested UI is just another hole in your coverage. </vent>
